content: The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. The "Individual Retirement Account Equity and Enhancement Act of 1994" allows homemakers to be eligible for a full IRA deduction. Spousal IRA rules are amended to base contributions on the compensation of both spouses. The compensation included in an individual's gross income for the taxable year, plus the compensation included in the spouse's gross income for the same year, reduced by any deduction allowed for the spouse. This applies to individuals filing a joint return. The provision applies to individuals filing a joint return where one spouse has less compensation included in their gross income compared to the other spouse. Amendments are made to section 219(f) to reflect this. Amendments to sections 408(d)(5) and 219(f) regarding compensation and effective dates for taxable years after December 31, 1994. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first homes, higher education, qualified long-term care expenses, or by the long-term unemployed. Distributions from certain plans can be used penalty-free for first homes, higher education, or long-term care expenses. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions, qualified higher education expenses, and qualified long-term care expenses can be made penalty-free from certain plans. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions allow individuals to use payments or distributions for qualified acquisition costs towards a first-time homebuyer's principal residence within 60 days penalty-free. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions allow penalty-free use of payments for qualified acquisition costs related to acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement, financing, and closing costs. Qualified first-time homebuyer distributions allow penalty-free use of payments for qualified acquisition costs related to acquiring, constructing, or reconstructing a residence, including settlement, financing, and closing costs. The term 'first-time homebuyer' refers to an individual who had no ownership interest in a principal residence during the past 3 years. The individual must have had no ownership interest in a principal residence for the 3-year period before acquiring the principal residence. The term 'principal residence' in section 1034 has the same meaning. The 'date of acquisition' refers to the date of a binding contract to acquire the principal residence. The distribution from an individual retirement plan must meet certain requirements related to the acquisition or construction of a principal residence. If there is a delay or cancellation in the acquisition, a special rule applies. If a distribution fails to meet residence acquisition requirements solely due to purchase delay or cancellation, the amount may be contributed to an individual retirement plan with certain exceptions. Qualified higher education expenses include tuition, fees, books, supplies, and equipment necessary for enrollment or attendance of the taxpayer, their spouse, or dependents. The taxpayer, spouse, or eligible family members attending an eligible educational institution can have qualified higher education expenses reduced by any excludable amount under section 135. The amount of qualified higher education expenses for any taxable year shall be reduced by any amount excludable from gross income under section 135. Qualified long-term care expenses refer to amounts paid for qualified long-term care services, including insurance covering such services. Qualified long-term care services include necessary diagnostic, preventive, therapeutic, rehabilitative, and maintenance services required by a functionally impaired individual. Qualified long-term care services are provided to functionally impaired individuals to assist with activities of daily living they are unable to perform. Functionally impaired individuals are unable to perform activities of daily living under a continuing plan of care prescribed by a licensed health care practitioner. "Functionally impaired individual' means an individual certified by a licensed health care practitioner as unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance." The definition of a "functionally impaired individual" includes someone unable to perform at least 3 activities of daily living without substantial assistance, especially in the case of home health care services. Activities of daily living include eating, transferring, and toileting. Licensed health care practitioner includes a physician or registered professional nurse for activities such as eating, transferring, toileting, dressing, and bathing. The curr_chunk states that a qualified individual, such as a physician, registered nurse, or community care case manager, can provide certain healthcare services as defined by the Secretary. The curr_chunk defines a qualified community care case manager as an individual or entity experienced in providing case management services and preparing care plans. A qualified community care case manager must have experience in providing case management services, assessing functional and cognitive impairment, not be a relative of the individual receiving services, and meet requirements set by the Secretary. The Secretary may prescribe penalty-free distributions for unemployed individuals under section 72(t), with the definition of "relative" specified in section 152(a). A new subparagraph is added to section 72(t) allowing penalty-free distributions from an individual retirement plan to unemployed individuals who have received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks. A new subparagraph in section 72(t) allows penalty-free distributions from an individual retirement plan to unemployed individuals who have received unemployment compensation for 12 consecutive weeks. Amendments to section 401(k)(2)(B)(i) include conditions for such distributions. The new subparagraph in section 72(t) allows penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses. The amendment in section 403(b)(11) allows penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses as defined in section 72(t). The amendment allows penalty-free distributions for qualified first-time homebuyer, higher education, and long-term care expenses as defined in section 72(t)(7) and 72(t)(8). The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of this Act.
